content: The "Bob Dole Congressional Gold Medal Act" recognizes Bob Dole's achievements and sacrifices during his life, including his service in WWII where he was seriously wounded while trying to save a fellow soldier. Bob Dole recovered from grave injuries in WWII and received multiple military awards. He later served in the Kansas House of Representatives, U.S. House of Representatives, and U.S. Senate, holding various leadership positions. Dole was known for his bipartisan approach. Bob Dole, a leader known for bipartisanship, advocacy for the disabled, and setting records as the longest-serving Republican Leader in the Senate. He was honored by several Presidents for his hard work and leadership, receiving the Presidential Citizens Medal from President Reagan in 1989. Bob Dole, a respected leader in Congress, was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1997 by President Clinton for his integrity, dedication, and commitment to keeping America united and strong. After his public service career, Dole continued to make a positive impact. Bob Dole continued to make a positive impact after his public service career by advocating for the public good. He raised millions for the National WWII Memorial and Families of Freedom Scholarship Fund, chaired the International Commission on Missing Persons, and established The Robert J. Dole Institute of Politics. In 2004, he received the Golden Medal of Freedom for his support of democracy in Kosovo. Bob Dole, a former politician, continued his advocacy work by supporting democracy and freedom in Kosovo, co-chairing a commission on medical care for wounded soldiers, co-creating a program to combat child hunger, co-founding a bipartisan policy center, and advocating for veterans through the Honor Flight Network. Bob Dole serves as Finance Chairman of the Campaign for the National Eisenhower Memorial in Washington, DC. He has been acknowledged by many organizations for his achievements in politics and public service, receiving numerous awards including the U.S. Senator John Heinz Award, the French Legion of Honor medal, and the Horatio Alger Award. Bob Dole has received numerous awards for his service, including the Congressional Gold Medal in recognition of his leadership and determination in politics and public service. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike a gold medal with suitable emblems for an award. Duplicates in bronze may be struck and sold under regulations set by the Secretary. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items under the law.
